occurrences.line_text: And dearest loue:
And for his dearest sake endured sore,
Her louer deare, her dearest Marinell,
Which was the dearest to his donghill mind,
But let vs go to seeke my dearest Dame,
And loue a Shepheards daughter for his dearest Dame.
His dearest loue, the comfort of his dayes,
That making way vnto his dearest life,
And Canacee gan wayle her dearest frend.
Of th'euill plight, in which her dearest brother
That workst such wrecke on her, to whom thou dearest art.
To bath their hands in bloud of dearest freend,
And you faire Ladie knight, my dearest Dame,
Her dearest loue full loth so shortly to forsake.
That likewise late had lost her dearest loue;
Ne any but your selfe, O dearest dred,
That lou'd me deare, as dearest thing aliue.
When he in place his dearest loue did spy;
Giuing her dearest children one by one
Though I this dearest life for her doe spend;
But most for pitty of his dearest Dame,
His dearest ioynt he sure had broken quight.
Then backe returning to his dearest deare,
Ah Satyrane, my dearling, and my ioy,
Do thou dred infant, Venus dearling doue,
Which keeper is this Dwarfe, her dearling base,
Those daintie parts, the dearlings of delight,
But with sharpe speare the rest made dearly knowne.
That she might win some time, though dearly bought
That Calidore it dearly deepe did moue.
They heard a ruefull voice, that dearnly cride
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
Hath made iudge of my life or death indifferently.
And fro me hid: of whose most innocent death
O too deare loue, loue bought with death too deare.
Still dreading death, when she had marked long,
That should as death vnto my deare hart light:
And eke my night of death the shadow is;
The cloud of death did sit. Which doen away,
And launcht his Lordly hart: with death opprest
Where brothers death to wreak Sansioy
For death it was, when any good he saw,
Ay me, that is a double death (she said)
The messenger of death, the ghastly Owle
In death auowing th'innocence of her sonne.
A fordonne wight from dore of death mote raise,
Till scornd of God and man a shamefull death he dide.
For doubtlesse death ensewd, if any him descryde.
Which quit from death yet quakes in euery lim
To dally thus with death, is no fit toy,
Then wonne from death, she bad him tellen plaine
Both hungred after death: both chose to win, or die.
But seeled vp with death, shall haue their deadly meed.
If death it be, it is not the first wound,
Wherein captiu'd, of life or death he stood in doubt.
That rather death desire, then such despight.
Death and despeyre did many thereof sup,
Of death, that here lye dying euery stound,
O welcome thou, that doest of death bring tydings trew.
A ruefull spectacle of death and ghastly drere.
And is the point of death now turnd fro mee,
With which sad instrument of hastie death,
None else to death this man despayring driue,
But his owne guiltie mind deseruing death.
Ease after warre, death after life does greatly please.
Or shunne the death ordaynd by destinie?
Whe[n] houre of death is come, let none aske whence, nor why.
Thou wretched man, of death hast greatest need,
Thy life shut vp, for death so oft did call;
Yet death then, would the like mishaps forestall,
Death is the end of woes: die soone, O faeries sonne.
That nought but death before his eyes he saw,
And bad him choose, what death he would desire:
For death was due to him, that had prouokt Gods ire.
But death he could not worke himselfe thereby;
And comfort those, in point of death which lay;
When sin, and hell, and death do most dismay
The seuenth now after death and buriall done,
The bitter doome of death and balefull mone
Dead was it sure, as sure as death in deed,
Death better were, death did he oft desire,
Death better were, death did he oft desire,
But death will neuer come, when needes require.
Into that same he fell: which did from death him saue.
That death him did awaite in dayly wretchednesse.
He could escape fowle death or deadly paines?
That none but death for euer can deuide;
And threatned death with many a bloudie word;
Death were too little paine for such a foule despight.
The sacred badge of my Redeemers death,
Yet can they not warne death from wretched wight.
Come then, come soone, come sweetest death to mee,
Of death and labour lay, halfe dead, halfe quicke,
On which the drery death did sit, as sad
As heauen accusing guiltie of her death,
Sad verse, giue death to him that death does giue,
Sad verse, giue death to him that death does giue,
And ended all her woe in quiet death.
Palmer (quoth he) death is an equall doome
But after death the tryall is to come,
But both alike, when death hath both supprest,
For all so great shame after death I weene,
T'auenge his Pare[n]ts death on them, that had it wrought.
And doest not vnto death thy selfe prepaire.
And threatned death with dreadfull countenaunce,
That death were better, then such agony,
Had doen to death, subdewde in equall frayes,
And cause of death betweene two doughtie knights doe breed.
The shame and death, which will thee soone inuade?
Nothing but death can doe me to respire.
After pursewing death once to require,
Death is for wretches borne vnder vnhappie starre.
O Atin, helpe to me last death to giue.
Of death and dolour telling sad tidings;
For next to death is Sleepe to be compard:
But dread of death and dolour doe away;
Or what doth his bad death now satisfy
Loe where the dreadfull Death behind thy backe doth stond.
Still waites for death with dread and trembling aw;
But in despight of life, for death do call.
All threatning death, all in straunge manner armd,
And threw in bands, where he till death remaind;
In which he dyde, made ripe for death by eld,
Whose death t'auenge, his mother mercilesse,
Till by his death he it recouered;
She triumphed on death, in enemies despight.
And Hengist eke soone brought to shamefull death.
But they to direfull death their groning ghosts did send.
To shunne Rocke of Reproch, and it as death to dred.
Of Death, and like him lookes in dreadfull hew,
For death sate on the point of that enchaunted speare.
That it importunes death and dolefull drerihed.
That death me liefer were, then such despight,
And yield the pray of loue to lothsome death at last.
For death nor daunger from thy dew reliefe
But it must doubled be with death of twaine?
For nought for me but death there doth remaine.
Till death make one end of my dayes and miserie.
So that needs loue or death must be thy lot,
That nought but death her dolour mote depart.
Ne doest by others death ensample take,
So life is losse, and death felicitie.
Sad life worse then glad death: and greater crosse
Sister of heauie death, and nourse of woe,
The drearie image of sad death appeares:
Our life is day, but death with darknesse doth begin.
And oft him threatned death for his outrageous wrong.
What bootes it him from death to be vnbound,
Faire death it is to shonne more shame, to dy:
And shund dishonor, which as death she feard:
She you from death, you me from dread redeemed.
To do fowle death to dye, or wrap in grieuous woe.
Two things he feared, but the third was death;
That he mote algates dye, yet did his death forgiue.
That had from death to life him newly wonne.
Was fowly dight, and he of death afeard.
That death and life attonce vnto him giues.
Endlesse renowm, that more then death is to be sought.
Whence dearely she with death bought her desire.
Yet was thy loue her death, & her death was thy smart.
Yet was thy loue her death, & her death was thy smart.
Vile Pouertie, and lastly Death with infamie.
Is death, or if that ought do death exceed,
Is death, or if that ought do death exceed,
He glad of life, that lookt for death but late,
Were sent, that seemed death in them to beare,
No lesse then death it selfe, in daungerous affright.
That seemed nought but death mote be her destinie.
Shall death be th'end, or ought else worse, aread.
Death is to him, that wretched life doth lead,
Then death it selfe more dread and desperate.
That vnto death had doen him vnredrest,
Damon and Pythias whom death could not seuer;
By timely death shall winne her wished rest,
And if ye deeme me death for louing one,
It's late in death of daunger to aduize,
By wicked doome condemn'd, a wretched death to die.
For death t'adward I ween'd did appertaine
Sad death, reuiued with her sweet inspection
Of death, the which them almost ouertooke,
For as the death he hated such despight,
and doth from death repriue.
Thinking to haue her griefe by death bereaued.
Twixt life and death, long to and fro she weaued,
When as the paine of death she tasted had,
For any death to chaunge life though most bad:
From dreadfull mouth of death, which threatned sore
That he of womens hands so base a death should dy.
And horrour of fowle death for Knight vnfit,
And pangs of death her spirit ouertooke.
That might haue had of life or death election:
That many hath with dread of death dismayd,
To thinke how this long death thou mightest disinherit.
Like fruitles seede, of which vntimely death should grow.
And tryumph in their blood, whom she to death did dryue.
That she of death was guiltie found by right,
Is liker lingring death, then loathed life to bee.
Whom she did put to death, deceiued like a foole.
She death shall by. Those tidings sad
Gainst which the pallid death findes no defence.
Appointed for Irenas death before,
That seemed nought could him from death protect:
That he for dread of death gan loude to crie
In dread of death, his heasts did gladly heare,
After whose death, his brother seeing mee
Twixt life and death, not knowing what was donne.
With stronger death, and feared their decay,
Whylest euery ioynt for dread of death did quake,
The fearefull swayne beholding death so nie,
Lay in the lap of death, rewing his wretched bale.
Or else abide the death, that hard before you stands.
Whose doome was death, but lightly slipping by,
My life will by his death haue lamentable end.
And to the dore of death for sorrow drew,
The rest that scape his sword and death eschew,
Yet fearing death, and next to death the lacke
Yet fearing death, and next to death the lacke
A thousand times him thankt, that had her death preuented.
It dearely shall aby, and death for handsell pay.
But making way for death at large to walke:
With cloud of death vpon her eyes displayd;
Renew'd her death by timely death denying:
Renew'd her death by timely death denying:
How could the death dare euer her to quell?
Their Captaine long withstood, & did her death forstall.
And death it selfe vnto himselfe did threat;
Or if that dead, how he her death might wreake,
And life to feele, that long for death had sought;
Into their caues, their heads from death to hide,
The man that would not liue, but earst lay at deathes dore.
Me liefer were ten thousand deathes priefe,
Shall I then hate her, that from deathes dore
That thousand deathes me leuer were to dye,
And doth transfixe the soule with deathes eternall dart.
Had deathes owne image figurd in her face,
That euery houre they knocke at deathes gate?
From deathes dore, at which he lately lay,
And dare euen deathes most dreadfull face behold?
Looking each houre into deathes mouth to fall,
His life was nigh vnto deaths doore yplast,
Whom these sad eyes saw nigh vnto deaths dore,
The ill-faste Owle, deaths dreadfull messengere,
Well knowing her to be his deaths sole instrument.
And byting th'earth for very deaths disdaine;
Sweet slo[m]bring deaw, the which to sleepe them biddes.
In siluer deaw his euer-drouping hed,
When morning deaw vpon their leaues doth light:
Of scorched deaw, do not in th'aire more lightly flee.
That all the ground with precious deaw bedight,
With perly deaw, and th'Earthes gloomy shade
Dropped with brackish deaw; his three-forkt Pyke
Thereon distill, and deaw her daintie face,
High brandishing his bright deaw-burning blade,
Deawd with ambrosiall kisses, by thee gotten
As it had deawed bene with timely raine:
Deawed with siluer drops, through sweating sore;
Deawed with siluer drops, that trickled downe alway.
Came dauncing forth, shaking his deawie haire:
Had spred her purple robe through deawy aire,
Out of the sea faire Titans deawy face,
And faire Aurora from the deawy bed
Cleare the deawy ayre with springing light,
His deawy face out of the sea doth reare:
And her faire deawy eies with kisses deare
She flong, and her faire deawy lockes yrent,
His deawy head out of the Ocean maine,
His watry eyes, drizling like deawy raine,
And sprinckled frost vpon his deawy beard:
In deawy vapours of the westerne maine,
From her faire eyes wiping the deawy wet,
From vnder which the deawy humour shed,
Like to the Euening starre adorn'd with deawy ray.
Her deawy humour gan on th'earth to shed,
Vtterers of secrets he from thence debard,
Tydings thereof, and so them still debar'd.
None was debard, but all had leaue that lust.
But at the sight of these, those were a while debard.
Shall me debarre, tell me therefore my liefest liefe.
And honour with indignitie debased:
Well could he tourney and in lists debate,
Strife; and debate, bloudshed, and bitternesse,
With him in bloudie armes they rashly did debate.
Not to debate the chalenge of your right,
So gan he to discourse the whole debate,
Who after long debate, since Lucies time,
With double senses, and with false debate,
And both full loth in darkenesse to debate;
And magnifying louers deare debate;
Her name was Ate, mother of debate,
Through mischieuous debate, and deadly feood,
Drew nigh, to weete the cause of their debate:
As als by this, that now a new debate
They liu'd together long without debate:
Cause of their discord, and so fell debate,
Then th'elder, and him maystred still in all debate.
Which he endured had through daungerous debate.
Ne any dares with him for it debate.
Himselfe addrest vnto this new debate,
Which Shepheards lead, without debate or bitter strife.
Debatefull strife, and cruell enmitie
He with Pyrrochles sharp debatement made;
Which on both sides was then debating hard:
Thus whylest they were debating diuerslie,
For the large leape, which Debon did compell
Corineus, and Coulin of Debon old
Was neuer Prince so meeke and debonaire;
Crying, Let be that Ladie debonaire,
Thereto so bounteous and so debonaire,
The bountiest virgin, and most debonaire,
Courteous to all, and seeming debonaire,
Most sacred wight, most debonayre and free,
And Debons shayre was, that is Deuonshyre:
But when I read, how stout Debora strake
For danger great, if not assur'd decay
Through wicked pride, and wasted wealthes decay.
In hope to bring her to her last decay.
O foolish men, why haste ye to your owne decay?
It could recure, and aged long decay
And giue you eke good helpe to their decay,
So shall wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue dye and decay.
But ouergrowne with dust and old decay,
Eternall God thee saue from such decay.
More glory thought to giue life, then decay,
Fly fast, and saue your selues from neare decay,
Threatning vnheedie wrecke and rash decay,
And preacht the truth, but since it greatly did decay.
And dayly spectacle of sad decay:
That now it gan to threaten neare decay:
To shunne the engin of his meant decay;
Or th'vtmost issew of his owne decay.
That he began to faint, and life decay:
That called was the VVhirlepoole of decay,
Ne more doth flourish after first decay,
Made them recoile, and fly from dred decay,
Till enuious Men fearing their rules decay,
To bring her sonne vnto his last decay.
For formes are variable and decay,
All things decay in time, and to their end do draw.
And is the spectacle of ruinous decay.
Her certaine losse, if not her sure decay:
And sought to bring all things vnto decay;
As blasted bloosme through heat doth languish & decay;
Of Amoret, so neare vnto decay,
That his decay should happen by a mayd.
Till they arriue at their last ruinous decay.
So did this Ladies goodly forme decay,
Of rude obliuion, and long times decay,
But tract of time, that all things doth decay,
But now when Philtra saw my lands decay,
Did aske, what cause brought that man to decay,
As for to lead your selfe vnto your owne decay?
With moniments of many knights decay,
The Sunnes bright wayne to Phaetons decay,
And when in wrath he threats the worlds decay,
She, glad of spoyle and ruinous decay,
Out of her poysnous entrails, fraught with dire decay.
For to receiue the doome of her decay.
And when I gin to feele decay of might,
With stronger death, and feared their decay,
Into her trap vnto their owne decay:
Vnto a straunge mischaunce, that menac'd her decay.
To sad decay, that might contented liue.
That mucky masse, the cause of mens decay,
Decayd, and all his flesh shronk vp like withered flowres.
She eke so often, as his life decayd,
So still his hart woxe sore, and health decayd:
How she might heale her sonne, whose senses were decayd.
Amoret, through charmes decayd.
She found, and all their glory quite decayd,
And now it is so vtterly decayd,
But now their forces greatly were decayd,
Whose liues although decay'd, yet loues decayed neuer.
Who as he still decayd, so he encreased more.
The sight of whom, though now decayd and mard,
Her louely light was dimmed and decayd,
But she now weighing the decayed plight,
Till he recouered had his late decayed plight.
And their decayed kingdomes shall amend:
Whose liues although decay'd, yet loues decayed neuer.
Ne when the life decayes, and forme does fade,
To cruell loue, and wrought their owne decayes:
But ah, her expectation greatly was deceau'd.
I read the man, that euer would deceaue
Him selfe he did of his new loue deceaue:
Whether by might extort, or else by slight deceaued.
But see how much her purpose was deceaued.
Duessa I, the daughter of Deceipt and Shame.
The false resemblance of Deceipt, I wist
By which deceipt doth maske in visour faire,
So, them deceiues, deceiu'd in his deceipt,
Shamefull deceipt, and daunger imminent;
By treacherous deceipt did me depriue;
Of such deceipt, kept th'yron dore fast bard,
So did deceipt the selfe deceiuer fayle,
No false enchauntment, nor deceiptfull traine
Eftsoones vntwisting his deceiptfull clew,
Which two through treason and deceiptfull gin,
And well perceiued his deceiptfull sleight,
And vsd to bath themselues in that deceiptfull shade.
But his deceiptfull eyes did neuer lin,
Ne euer did deceiptfull Clarin find
She wounded was with her deceipts owne dart,
And seuerall deceipts, but all in vaine:
With cup thus charmd, him parting she deceiu'd;
And with selfe-loued personage deceiu'd,
So, them deceiues, deceiu'd in his deceipt,
But when he stroke most strong, the dint deceiu'd,
Deceiu'd of gealous Iuno, did require
But glauncing by, deceiu'd him of that he desynd.
For all he did, was to deceiue good knights,
For sure it would deceiue thy labour, and thy might.
But ah, who can deceiue his destiny,
And louely face, made fit for to deceiue
Who louers will deceiue. Thus was the ape,
Vaine is the art that seekes it selfe for to deceiue.
Withholdes it to her selfe, and doeth deceiue
Me to deceiue of faith vnto me plight,
That could deceiue one looking in his face;
And empty sides deceiued of their dew,
Was of his forward hope deceiued quight;
And dayly more deceiued was thereby;
Deceiued through great likenesse of their face.
And drawing backe deceiued their intent;
Least by such slight he were vnwares deceiued;
Whom she did put to death, deceiued like a foole.
As if she doubted to haue bene deceiued,
So did deceipt the selfe deceiuer fayle,
So, them deceiues, deceiu'd in his deceipt,
Without remorse, or decent funerall:
After her Noble husbands late decesse;
The second not so strong but wise, Decetto;
So did Decetto eke him circumuent,
But if ye please, that I your cause decide,
That, which he doth with righteous doome decide,
And deck with dainty flowres their bridall bed,
And deck the world with their rich pompous showes;
Whom all the people decke with girlands greene,
Fit to adorne the dead, and decke the drery toombe.
To decke his herce, and trap his tomb-blacke steed.
To decke my song withall, I would assay,
Did decke her, and too lauishly adorne,
That earst was sought to decke both bed and bowre,
And with fresh colours decke the wanton Prime,
Ten thousand fishes play, and decke his pleasant streame.
Plenty of pearles to decke his dames withall,
And foule defame doe decke thy bloudy baner?
Which decke to body or adorne the mynde,
And euery pillour decked was full deare
Decked with diuerse plumes, like painted Iayes,
And the faire flowres, that decked him afore;
That now with thousand starres was decked fayre;
Decked with many a costly ornament,
The charet decked was in wondrous wize,
All decked in a robe of watchet hew,
Then came the Rother, decked all with woods
And deckes his branch with blossomes ouer all,
And with greene boughes decking a gloomy glade,
Decking her cheeke with a vermilion rose:
That decks and armes your shield with faire defence:
Loe loe how braue she decks her bounteous boure,
And decks the girlonds of her paramoures,
And deckt himselfe with feathers youthly gay,
Did thus reuest, and deckt with due habiliments.
And shewd them naked, deckt with many ornaments.
For why should a dead dog be deckt in armour bright?
And deckt with flowers and herbars daintily;
Are deckt with blossomes dyde in white and red,
With diuerse flowres he daintily was deckt,
Mote Princes place beseeme so deckt to bee.
That deckt the azure field with her faire pouldred skin.
With which high God his workmanship hath deckt;
Him shaped thus, she deckt in garments gay,
And her bright browes were deckt with borrowed haire:
Her selfe so deckt, her nimble wings displaid,
All deckt with crownes, & chaynes, and girlands gay,
Were deckt with smyles, that all sad humors chaced,
And deckt with pearles, which th'Indian seas for her prepaire.
All goodly damzels, deckt with long greene haire,
Fresh Alimeda, deckt with girlond greene;
To Isis, deckt with Mitre on her hed,
Deckt all the roofe, and shadowing the roode,
Deckt with greene boughes, and flowers gay beseene.
Yet deckt with wondrous giftes of natures grace,
And deckt it all with flowres, which they nigh hand obtayned.
That day should faile me, ere I had them all declard.
And all those daungers vnto them declar'd,
Declar'd the message, which that Knight did moue;
Making obeyssance, did the cause declare,
Then gan the Dwarfe the whole discourse declare,
And came to Coelia to declare her smart,
Deare Lady how shall I declare thy cace,
Dreadlesse (said he) that shall I soone declare:
That all her goodly deeds do well declare.
It were a goodly storie, to declare,
But to declare the mournfull Tragedyes,
Ah dreadfull tidings which thou doest declare,
And why? doe it declare vnto me trew.
Declare at once; and hath he lost or wun?
Then gan she to declare the whole discourse
Who them to their posterities doe still declare.
